container.eli5: A container is like a lunchbox that holds your app and everything it needs to run.
container.boss: A container packages software and its dependencies into a portable unit, ensuring consistent behavior across environments.
container.sysadmin: Containers are isolated, lightweight runtime environments that package applications with their libraries, often using Docker or OCI standards.
container.use_case: Used to deploy a web server in a reproducible, isolated environment.

image.eli5: An image is like a recipe card for making containers—it tells the computer how to build one.
image.boss: A container image is a read-only template used to create running containers.
image.sysadmin: Images are layered filesystem snapshots including binaries, libraries, and metadata; built with Dockerfiles or similar tools.
image.use_case: Used to spin up identical containers on different machines.

volume.eli5: A volume is like a USB stick you plug into your lunchbox so it doesn’t forget your notes.
volume.boss: Volumes provide persistent storage for containers beyond their life cycle.
volume.sysadmin: Volumes are managed storage drivers mounted into containers, used for data persistence and shared filesystems.
volume.use_case: Used to store database data that survives container restarts.

bind_mount.eli5: It’s like giving your lunchbox a direct view into your kitchen’s fridge.
bind_mount.boss: A bind mount links a container folder to a host directory for shared access.
bind_mount.sysadmin: Bind mounts map host filesystem paths directly into a container’s filesystem, often used for live development or logs.
bind_mount.use_case: Used to mount configuration files from the host into containers.

network_mode.eli5: It’s like choosing if your lunchbox shares the same phone as the house or has its own number.
network_mode.boss: Network mode defines how a container connects to other services or the internet.
network_mode.sysadmin: Docker network modes include bridge, host, none, and container—configuring container IP stack isolation or sharing.
network_mode.use_case: Used to give a container full access to the host network stack for better performance.

healthcheck.eli5: It’s like a daily checkup that tells you if your lunchbox is still working.
healthcheck.boss: Healthchecks are periodic tests to confirm a container or service is running as expected.
healthcheck.sysadmin: Docker healthchecks define a command in the container that runs at intervals; if it fails, the container is marked unhealthy.
healthcheck.use_case: Used to restart a service if it becomes unresponsive or fails the healthcheck.

port_mapping.eli5: It’s like giving your toy a door number so friends know where to visit.
port_mapping.boss: Port mapping allows external users to access services inside containers through specific host ports.
port_mapping.sysadmin: Maps a container’s internal port (e.g. 80) to a host port (e.g. 8080) for network accessibility outside the container.
port_mapping.use_case: Used to expose a web service from a container to the host machine on port 8080.

entrypoint.eli5: It’s the first thing your lunchbox does when it wakes up.
entrypoint.boss: Entrypoint defines the default command that runs when a container starts.
entrypoint.sysadmin: Entrypoint in Docker specifies the main process to run inside the container, configurable via Dockerfile or CLI.
entrypoint.use_case: Used to set a Python script as the main process for a container.

alpine_image.eli5: It’s like a mini lunchbox—super light and simple but still useful.
alpine_image.boss: Alpine is a lightweight Linux-based container image that minimizes size and attack surface.
alpine_image.sysadmin: The Alpine Docker image is under 5MB and uses musl and BusyBox, ideal for minimal containers.
alpine_image.use_case: Used to reduce container size in microservices for faster build and deploy.

multi_arch_image.eli5: It’s like a toy that works in both big and small toy houses without needing changes.
multi_arch_image.boss: Multi-arch images let the same container run on different CPU architectures like x86 and ARM.
multi_arch_image.sysadmin: Multi-architecture images bundle multiple platform variants using Docker manifests (e.g., amd64, arm64).
multi_arch_image.use_case: Used to deploy the same image to both Raspberry Pi and x86_64 servers.
